title: How to Catch White Sea Bass

steps.headline: Take note of the best seasons to catch white sea bass.
steps.description: Starting around March, white sea bass are abundant near Catalina Island, San Clemente Island, and the Northern Channel Islands that include Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, San Miguel, San Nicolas and Santa Barbara Island in California. Summer is the best season for fishing for sea bass in Southern California, but they can be caught into the fall and winter months. However, most people focus on other types of game fish during the cooler months.

steps.headline: Obtain the right bait.
steps.description: White sea bass are very selective when it comes to what they will bite. Early spring white sea bass are typically caught with live or freshly dead squid. White sea bass caught in the summer or later months are not as picky and can be caught on almost any bait or jig.

steps.headline: Attach the line, hook, and other accessories to your fishing pole.
Use a white iron jig in combination with 2 live squid for your first attempt.
steps.description: White sea bass enjoy larger amounts of food, and the 2-squid combination is hard for them to resist. This kind of bait oftentimes attracts larger white sea bass, so make sure you are using a line that can hold at least 40 pounds (18 kg).

steps.headline: Use a medium-sized mackerel if the previous bait didn't work.
steps.description: Using larger bait will prevent smaller fish from attacking your bait while attracting the white sea bass. Let the mackerel swim freely, and keep a close eye on it. Once the white sea bass is hooked, start reeling it in.

steps.headline: Let your iron jig or live bait go deep into the water if the previous 2 steps didn't work.
steps.description: This technique works best when attempting to fish for white sea bass during the spring and early summer months. You want to get the attention of the barracuda, which are often followed by the white sea bass. Mackerel works well in this situation because the barracuda will typically not try to feed on it. If a recently-caught white sea bass happens to swim by, this can be an opportunity to catch it in its weakened state.
